channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Birmingham Journal: Reading, Writing and Allegations: Muslim School at Center of Debate
item.description: In a heavily Muslim part of Birmingham, residents are uneasy as the state watches for evidence of a purported takeover by Islamists in their schools.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Maja Daniels for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students and teachers at Park View School in a heavily Muslim area of Birmingham, England.

item.title: Gerry Conlon, Imprisoned in I.R.A. Attack and Freed After 15 Years, Dies at 60
item.description: Mr. Conlon was a member of the so-called Guildford Four, whose convictions in deadly 1974 bombings in the London area were later quashed.
item.category: In the Name of the Father (Movie)
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gerry Conlon in 2005, the year he received a public apology.

item.title: Candidate Says Recordings Show Afghan Election Was Rigged
item.description: Abdullah Abdullah accused a top election official of colluding with his rival, Ashraf Ghani, to steal the presidency.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abdullah Abdullah’s campaign said the recordings are evidence a top election official was colluding with a rival, Ashraf Ghani.

item.title: Relief Over U.S. Exit From Iraq Fades as Reality Overtakes Hope
item.description: A president who thought he had set Iraq on a stable course without American help has now determined that American diplomacy and power are critical to saving it.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. greeting soldiers returning from Iraq in December 2011.

item.title: British Prime Minister to Undertake a Calculated Risk in Bucking Brussels
item.description: The British leader is opposing the likely choice to lead the European Commission, a stand that may serve him well at home.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: In a politically risky move, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, left, is expected to oppose the selection of Jean-Claude Juncker, right, as the next head of the European Commission.

item.title: Fouad Ajami Is Dead at 68; Expert in Arab History
item.description: Mr. Ajami, an academic and commentator on Middle East affairs, strove to put Arab history into a larger perspective and often said terrorism was one result of Muslim rage over losing power to the West in the 17th century.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: Iraq’s Military Seen as Unlikely to Turn the Tide
item.description: Recent assessments by Western officials and military experts indicate that about a quarter of Iraq’s military forces are “combat ineffective.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Iraqi soldier trying on a new uniform at a store in Baghdad. Some experts have declared the Iraqi Army a defeated force.

item.title: Fate of 3 Kidnapped Israelis Raises Tensions on Many Fronts
item.description: A kidnapping highlights the huge gulf, political and psychological, between long-warring neighbors and is raising fears of a third intifada in the Palestinian territories.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: In a show of solidarity, Jason Gardner and five friends prayed at the Western Wall in Jerusalem.

item.title: Putin Attempts to Straddle a Divide He Helped to Pry Open in Ukraine
item.description: Russia’s charged balancing act in its policy toward Ukraine has become evident, with President Vladimir V. Putin both endorsing a peace plan outlined by the Ukrainian president and rebuking Kiev for the shaky cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Sunday attended a commemoration of the 73rd anniversary of Nazi Germany’s invasion of the Soviet Union in Moscow.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Cyberattack on Hong Kong Vote Was Among Largest Ever, Security Chief Says
item.description: The distributed denial-of-service attack commanded a network of compromised computers around the world in an apparent attempt to overwhelm polling on Hong Kong’s political future.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Kerry Says U.S. Is Ready to Renew Ties With Egypt
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry expressed confidence that the United States would soon restore aid to Egypt, including $1.3 billion annually to the military.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry met with Sameh Shoukry, the Egyptian foreign minister, after his arrival in Cairo.

item.title: Israel Strikes Syria After Youth Is Killed
item.description: The Israeli military said it had targeted nine Syrian Army positions, including a headquarters and launching areas. The extent of any damage or casualties was not clear.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in the Golan Heights after an Israeli teenager was killed by fire from Syria.

item.title: 3 Who Escaped Prison by Helicopter Are Caught in Montreal
item.description: The prisoners, who are associated with the Hells Angels in northern Quebec, were captured by a heavily armed tactical unit that broke down the door of an apartment in Old Montreal.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: From left, Serge Pomerleau, Yves Denis and Denis Lefebvre were captured by a tactical unit at an Old Montreal apartment.

item.title: Poll on Democracy Draws Big Turnout in Hong Kong
item.description: Three days into a 10-day voting period, more than 600,000 ballots have been cast in a nonbinding poll on the selection of a leader for the city of seven million.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Kerry Hints That U.S. Would Support New Leader for Iraq
item.description: In Cairo on the first leg of a Middle East trip, Secretary of State John Kerry suggested that the United States would be open to a new Iraqi leader, while trying not to appear to intervene.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry met with Sameh Shoukry, the Egyptian foreign minister, after his arrival in Cairo.

item.title: Ayatollah of Iran Says U.S. Should Avoid Iraq
item.description: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said the dispute is “between those who want Iraq to join the U.S. camp and those who seek an independent Iraq.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Militants Take Major Border Post; Kerry Hints U.S. Is Open to a New Premier
item.description: Fighters and weapons are now able to move across the Iraq-Syria border with ease after a three-day fight for Qaim, a development that officials called worrisome.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: A Kurdish soldier in Sulaiman Pek in Iraq’s Salahuddin Province. Farther west, Sunni rebels seized Qaim near the Syrian border.

item.title: Tapes Said to Reveal Polish Minister Disparaging U.S. Ties
item.description: In a new excerpt from secretly recorded conversations, Foreign Minister Radoslaw Sikorski is quoted as describing his country’s security relationship with the United States as “worth nothing.”
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Turkey's Best Ally: The Kurds
item.description: After decades of strife, Ankara is cooperating with former enemies.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MUSTAFA AKYOL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Debt Vultures' Fell Swoop
item.description: A small group of “holdout” bondholders has used U.S. courts to hold Argentines ransom over their country’s 2001 default.
item.dc:creator: By MARK WEISBROT

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Fooling Mexican Fans
item.description: Mexico’s politicians are pushing through unpopular legislation, while its people are glued to the World Cup.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCISCO GOLDMAN
item.media:description: Protesters demonstrated this spring in Mexico City against energy reform that would open up the nationalized oil company to foreign investment. Recently, debates on the reform were scheduled at the same time as the World Cup tournament.

item.title: Open Source: Activists Arrested in Cairo at March Against Protest Ban
item.description: Police arrested Egyptians protesting a new law banning unsanctioned street protests on Saturday in Cairo, activists said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A group of unidentified men attacked a protest in Cairo on Saturday, throwing rocks and bottles, before the police moved in and arrested demonstrators.

item.title: Fugitive Trades Fire With Troops in South Korea
item.description: An army sergeant who killed five fellow soldiers engaged in a shootout with troops chasing him on Sunday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Hong Jin-Hwan-Donga Daily, via Getty Images
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers searched on Sunday for a South Korean Army sergeant who fled his unit on the border with North Korea after killing five fellow soldiers.

item.title: Political Upstarts Work to Propel Change in an Indonesia Tired of Corruption
item.description: A small but growing group of political upstarts is emerging and its members seem united in a belief that the Indonesian public is fed up with the level of corruption in the nation.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Joko Widodo, known as the leader of a new wave of politicians, at a mosque in Central Java, Indonesia, this month.

item.title: Ukrainian Church Faces Obscure Pro-Russia Revolt in Its Own Ranks
item.description: Many in western Ukraine suspect that the breakaway church represents a Russian-backed maneuver to destroy a vital wellspring of Ukrainian nationalism.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A priest pouring water on a baby during a blessing ceremony for newborns held at St. George’s Cathedral in Lviv, Ukraine.
